user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const char *Str, size_t DataLen)
{
    ssize_t WriteLen;

    while (DataLen > 0)
    {
        /* writes the raw data directly to STDOUT_FILENO (unbuffered) */
        WriteLen = write(STDOUT_FILENO, Str, DataLen);
        if (WriteLen <= 0)
        {
            /* no recourse if this fails, just stop. */
            break;
        }
        Str += WriteLen;
        DataLen -= WriteLen;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
void UT_BSP_EndTest(const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char Message[128];

    /*
     * Only output a "summary" if there is more than one test Segment.
     * Otherwise it is a duplicate of the report already given.
     */
    if (TestCounters->TestSegmentCount > 1)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport("SUMMARY", TestCounters);
    }

    snprintf(Message, sizeof(Message), "COMPLETE: %u tests Segment(s) executed\n\n",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount);

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Message, strlen(Message));
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if ((TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE] > 0) ||
        (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF] > 0) || (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF] > 0))
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_ERROR);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_SUCCESS);
    }
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
DataLen -= WriteLen;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Within OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl the parameter DataLen (declared as size_t DataLen) is modified by the statement 'DataLen -= WriteLen;'. This directly violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter shall not be modified). Note: the function also modifies the pointer parameter Str via 'Str += WriteLen;', which likewise violates the rule's requirement that the pointer itself shall not be modified.
